Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Integration of Psychosocial Care in Orthopaedic Trauma Treatment

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were adults with musculoskeletal trauma meeting specific eligibility criteria.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with musculoskeletal trauma meeting specific eligibility criteria.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received psychological first aid, psychoeducation, and social support, while the control group received standard orthopaedic care.

Objective.evidence: To assess the effect of psychosocial care on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms and functional recovery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in PTSD symptoms, measured over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation concealment was ensured using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 allocated to each group between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in PTSD symptoms (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.

Funding.evidence: This study did not receive any specific funding from public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
